instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this lineâ€™s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi, USB-C shows 20V with cycling amperage from 0 to 0.025A

<DIODE>D6905</DIODE>:
pin 1: 1mV
pin 2: 20.5V

<RESISTOR>R7030</RESISTOR> shows pp3v3 is at 3.39V

L7030 is at 12mV

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
"<RESISTOR>R7030</RESISTOR> shows pp3v3 is at 3.39V"
What is the relation between both???

Post basic voltages of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
"RST: 0"
Do you mean <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*?
Really strange, as per schematic that is <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.
I wonder how do you get 20V at USB-C ports, if SMC is kept in reset.
Please, check again <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> level.

You expect help, but you don't even take your time to properly write the signal names.
Did you ever see one of my posts writen in such way???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Yes, I did mean <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL> was 0, and on the second measurement, <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.42V and not 0 I must've had my multimeter prongs on it wrong and [B]I apologize, It happens sometimes, I'm not perfect.[/B]

I figured you would understand my abbreviation of RST because [B]every signal you just listed was an abbreviation [/B]and I had to spend time in the board view looking at the 40 pins of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to find which ones you were requesting.

I assumed the <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> you wanted was ppvin because there is no <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, there also was no <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL> and I found <SIGNAL>BANJO_ENVR1</SIGNAL> across the board because, in the off chance that's what you were referring to, I didn't want you to write another comment like the one you just wrote:
 " You expect help, but you don't even take your time to properly write the signal names."

[U][B]If I'm wrong and there is <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL> I will gladly show you my board view because I do not see that.[/B]

I'm not trying to make your job difficult[/U], I'm doing my best to give you the information that you need as quickly as I can. I don't have the expert knowledge that you do about every signal on the boards, if I did I wouldn't be posting here.

In [URL='https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a-<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-2012.61132/#post-74995']this post[/URL] and [URL='https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a-<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-2012.61132/#post-75001']this post[/URL] you listed out the signal names [B]without[/B] abbreviations and I was quick to find the values for you and there was no confusion from either party.

[URL='https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a.61230/']In this post[/URL] I tried to make everything organized and clear for you, and it was an oversight to not list everything in the same order and you were quick to tell me otherwise, which is why in this current post I kept the AUX, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>  and Amon and Bmon together, to make sense because that's how you wanted in the past.

[URL='https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-no-battery.61266/']In this post[/URL] I tried to make it even more clear with tables to make your job easier and to help me easier/faster.

Then I tried to explain to you I didn't understand which signals you wanted because you gave me [B]abbreviated[/B] "SCL/SDA" and I had to spend extra time just typing SCL and SDA into the board view but wasn't sure if <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL> was what you wanted or if it was one of the other 10+ signals that have SCL and SDA in it

Then you made this comment:
"No idea, looking at battery connector in schematic???" 

Don't you think that's exactly what I was doing? I was in the board view and didn't understand which ones you specifically needed because, again, it was [B]abbreviated [/B]and not the exact signal or even close enough that I could get the right signal with confidence. Simply searching SCL or SDA returns a ton of signals.

I'm not trying to make your job difficult[U][B] I greatly appreciate the work you do[/B][/U] for this forum and I envy your knowledge. But I would like some more patience from you because comments like:

"No idea, looking at battery connector in schematic??? "
 " You expect help, but you don't even take your time to properly write the signal names. "

are not necessary comments.

I'm trying my best to comb through all the 40 pins on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to figure out what <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL> are so you can help me as quickly as possible.

I understand the frustration you must encounter with all the posts on this forum, but I'm here to learn how to fix boards sir, this is my livelihood right now, I don't want to be belittled by your unnecessary comments, I'm learning.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
Once you work with Apple stuff, I considered you should have some experience.

Anything who replies here will check schematic, NOT boardview; unless special requirement is needed.
YOU MUST find corresponding reference in boardview.
I gave you the signal names inside <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, which are shorter.
Just need to see external name and find that in boardview.

However, you should know that Apple still has signal names in schematics which don't correspond with the names in boardview.
In such case, good enough to check the corresponding pin of a component.

About SCL/SDA abreviation.
Which bus do you think is referred, if the post is dedicated to the battery (for example)???

My reaction about RST?
0V on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> was impossible in this case; as you get 20V at USB-C ports.
So I needed to clarify the situation.

"<RESISTOR>R7030</RESISTOR> shows pp3v3 is at 3.39V"
I still didn't understand what yo've meant...

Finally, I appologise if I offended you.
You understood me wrong, that was not my intention.
